child.pub-comments: "Bare is a term apaprently used for several Maipurean Arawakan languages of the area: bare, Mandawaka, Warekena, Baniwa and Piapoko, according to Ethnologue." (66)

child.pub-comments: "The subgrouping of the Upper Amazon branch is very difficult, since most of the languages are dead and scantily documented. The living or well-documented languages can be grouped fairly well, but the remainder of the tentative classification given here is subject to some improvement." (65)

child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 65-67. London, New York: Routledge.
child.pub-comments: "Kalhiphona and Garifuna get their names from the Kariban word /karipona/, which is their autonym. It was imposed on the Inyeris by their conquerors, Kariban men who eventually learned the Inyeri language while keeping a sizable vocabulary of Kariban origin for use among men." (66)

child.geography: North Honduras, Southeast Guatemala, South Belize, Nicaragua
child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 65-67. London, New York: Routledge.
child.pub-comments: "Kalhiphona and Garifuna get their names from the Kariban word /karipona/, which is their autonym. (66) Speakers: 197000

child.pub-comments: "The Taíno language was spoken on all the large islands of the Carribean. It was the source of numerous lexical borrowings into the Spanish of the Carribean, and later of Meso-America and northern South America." (66)

Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 65-67. London, New York: Routledge.
child.pub-comments: "The Maipurean or Arawakan stock contains more distinct languages than any other family in the western hemisphere, and is internally more diverse than any other South American genetic group. The name Arawakan is the one normally applied to what here is called Maipurean. Maipurean used to be thought of as a major subgroup of Arawakan, but all the living Arawakan languages, at least, seem to need to be subgrouped with languages already found within Maipurean as commonly defined. The sorting of the labels Maipurean and Arawakan will have to await a more sophisticated classification of the languages in question than is possible at the present state of comparative studies." (65)

child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 65-67. London, New York: Routledge.
child.pub-comments: The group was wiped out by measles in 1877.

child.pub-comments: "Arawakan proper (or Maipurean) and Arawan are widely believed to form a family. Matteson included Arawan in her Arawakan reconstruction, but without much success. There is no doubt that Arawan is typologically like Arawakan, but that the relationship, if real, is not very close." (67)

child.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 65-67. London, New York: Routledge.

root.publications: Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 65-67. London, New York: Routledge.
root.pub-comments: "All the genetic units assigned to the macro-Arawakan belong to Greenberg's more inclusive 'Equatorial'. Both Swadesh and Loukotka link Wahivoan to Arawakan/Maipurean, and Suarez links Arawan to Arawakan/Maipurean. Greenberg links all three in his 'macro-Arawakan'. Matteson (1972) simply included Arawan within Arawakan in her rudimentary effort to reconstruct the latter. See Kaufman (1990) for a slightly different (and more inclusive) formulation." (65) The author calls this a cluster, which, according to him, is a grouping with time depth greater than 50 centuries which more than two scholar agree upon.
